item.title: Nutritional support could prevent tuberculosis deaths, cases in India by 2035: Lancet study - CNBCTV18
item.description:
Nutritional Support Could Prevent TB Deaths and Cases in India by 2035: Lancet Study

Publication Date: Not specified in the article.

Source: The Lancet Global Health

This study indicates that providing nutritional support to half of the households undergoing tuberculosis (TB) treatment in India may significantly reduce TB deaths and cases by 2035.

  • Approximately 4.5% of TB-related deaths might be prevented.
  • About 2.2% of TB disease episodes could be averted.
  • Estimates suggest that more than 360,000 deaths and over 880,000 TB cases could be averted.
  • The intervention may cost about USD 1,349 million but offers a potential economic benefit of USD 167 per disability-adjusted life-year averted.
  • An earlier study by the same research team revealed a drop in TB incidence by 39-48% through nutritional support for household contacts of TB patients.
  • The findings suggest a greater focus on states with high levels of undernutrition could enhance effectiveness.
“We found that if India can deliver a nutritional intervention to 50% of households in which individuals are receiving tuberculosis treatment, nearly 900,000 episodes of tuberculosis would be averted, and nearly 400,000 deaths, at a cost of USD 167 per disability-adjusted life-year averted,” the authors wrote.

In conclusion, nutritional support is a cost-effective approach likely to yield substantial health and economic benefits in combating tuberculosis in India.

item.title: Optimal delivery of pain management in schwannomatosis: challenges and | TCRM - Dove Medical Press
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Cracking the code of the extracellular matrix - The Transmitter: Neuroscience News and Perspectives
item.description:
Cracking the code of the extracellular matrix

Publication Date: October 2023
Source: Unknown

This article explores the significant role of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in brain function, detailing how ECM proteins influence neuronal plasticity, learning, and their potential implications for neurodegenerative diseases.

  • The discovery that ECM digestion can restore visual cortex plasticity after the critical period.
  • Up to 20% of the brain consists of ECM, which plays various roles in synaptic function and myelin formation.
  • ECM proteins could be crucial for what makes human brains unique and healthy.
  • Recent studies tie ECM proteins to youthfulness in brain biomarkers and their dysregulation in Alzheimer's disease.
  • The ECM field in neuroscience has been underexplored despite its importance.
  • Challenges remain with scientific blind spots and technical limitations in studying ECM proteins.
  • Advances in proteomics and a shift in thinking are necessary to fully understand the ECM and its implications for brain research.
“If the matrix involves the same degree of complexity and precision, the potential payoff for our understanding of brain plasticity and brain diseases could be immense.”

Overall, the article emphasizes the need for collaboration in neuroscience to address the complexities of the ECM and its role in brain function.

item.title: A golden age of cancer treatment? – podcast - The Guardian
item.description:
A Golden Age of Cancer Treatment? – Podcast

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Guardian

This article discusses advances in cancer treatment that have transformed options available for patients, including personalized treatments and new technologies, while acknowledging ongoing challenges.

  • Historically, cancer treatment options were limited to surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.
  • Billions of dollars have been invested in new cancer treatment technologies, including immunotherapy and artificial intelligence.
  • Despite advancements, challenges remain in the distribution of these new technologies to patients globally.
  • The article highlights personal stories, such as that of Abbie Halls, who participated in a successful clinical trial.
“How to distribute these expensive new technologies to everyone who needs them?”

The advancements in cancer treatment are promising, but attention is needed to ensure equitable access to these innovative therapies.

item.title: How vitamin B12 deficiency can affect adults dangerously - The Times of India
item.description:
How Vitamin B12 Deficiency Can Dangerously Affect Adults

Publication Date: N/A Source: Times of India

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a significant health concern that can lead to serious consequences for adults, impacting neurological function and overall health.

  • Vitamin B12 is crucial for proper nerve function and the production of DNA and red blood cells.
  • Deficiency can result in symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, constipation, and cognitive disturbances.
  • Long-term deficiency can lead to irreversible neurological damage if left untreated.
  • Older adults and individuals with certain dietary restrictions are at higher risk.
"Vitamin B12 is vital for maintaining health, and its deficiency can dangerously impair bodily functions."

Addressing vitamin B12 deficiency is essential for preventing serious health risks, making awareness and dietary adjustments crucial.

item.title: Diabetics, here’s what happens to the body if you skip breakfast - The Indian Express
item.description:
Diabetics, here’s what happens to the body if you skip breakfast

Publication Date: January 17, 2025

Source: Indian Express

For those with diabetes, breakfast is critical for maintaining balanced blood sugar levels and supporting overall health. Skipping breakfast can lead to both physiological and psychological complications.

  • Skipping breakfast can lead to elevated blood sugar levels later in the day.
  • It can worsen insulin resistance.
  • Missing this essential meal increases the risk of long-term health complications.
  • Breakfast provides vital nutrients necessary for metabolic balance.
  • It can lead to psychological effects such as mood swings and increased hunger.

Healthy breakfast tips for diabetics

Individuals with diabetes should prioritize a well-balanced breakfast, including low glycaemic index carbohydrates, lean proteins, healthy fats, and fibre-rich foods.

“To optimise blood sugar control, individuals with diabetes should prioritize a well-balanced breakfast,” said Kanikka Malhotra, consultant dietician and diabetes educator.

item.title: Coffee in the morning is best for heart health, says study: Can this routine work for you? - The Indian Express
item.description:
Coffee in the morning is best for heart health, says study: Can this routine work for you?

Date: January 17, 2025 Source: Indian Express

The study suggests that drinking coffee in the morning may lead to lower risks of cardiovascular diseases compared to consuming it throughout the day.

  • Morning coffee drinkers are 31% less likely to die from cardiovascular disease.
  • The study involved 40,725 adults in the US.
  • Dr. Komal Shah highlights the importance of sleep quality and its relation to coffee consumption timing.
  • Overconsumption of caffeine can lead to heightened blood pressure and poor sleep quality.
  • Moderate coffee consumption under 300 mg per day is recommended.
“These findings suggest that morning coffee consumption may have beneficial effects on cardiovascular health at the population level.” - Study conclusion

Overall, the study advocates for morning coffee as a healthier routine that could protect against heart-related issues, emphasizing moderation and timing in consumption.

item.title: Lancet commission proposes new definition for obesity: All you need to know - The Indian Express
item.description:
Lancet commission proposes new definition for obesity: All you need to know

Publication Date: January 14, 2023 | Source: The Lancet

A new definition and method for diagnosing obesity has been proposed by a commission from The Lancet. This aims to improve the accuracy of diagnosing obesity beyond the conventional BMI standards.

  • The Lancet Diabetes & Endocrinology Commission, consisting of 58 experts, finds BMI alone inadequate for diagnosing obesity.
  • New definitions include 'Preclinical Obesity' where it identifies excess body fat without illness.
  • Dr. Anoop Misra notes that Indians often face obesity-related health issues even with lower BMI scores.
  • Different measurement approaches beyond BMI are suggested, including waist circumference and DEXA scans.
  • Indian definitions reflect similar guidelines but maintain familiar BMI thresholds for ease of implementation.
Dr. Anoop Misra stated, “Using medicines to treat a person with a high BMI but no other condition or symptoms is just injudicious use of the medicine.”

The new guidelines aim to enhance diagnostic precision to inform treatment options, encouraging racial and regional adaptiveness in obesity classification.

item.title: US CDC recommends faster testing for bird flu in hospitalized patients - ETHealthWorld
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Study relates exposure to air pollution prior to conceiving with higher BMI in children - ETHealthWorld
item.description:
Study relates exposure to air pollution prior to conceiving with higher BMI in children

Date: January 17, 2025 Source: PTI

A recent study published in the journal Environmental Research has found a connection between increased air pollution exposure before pregnancy and higher BMI in children.

  • The study analyzed data from over 5,800 mother-child pairs in China.
  • Increased PM2.5 levels by 16.2 micrograms per cubic metre were linked to a rise of 0.078 in child BMI Z-scores at age two.
  • An increase in PM10 pollution by 21.1 micrograms per cubic metre was also associated with an increase of 0.093 in child BMI.
  • Researchers emphasized the need for potential measures to lower air pollution exposure for those planning to conceive.
The magnitude is small, but because air pollution is widespread and everybody is exposed, the risk of exposure on children's obesity may be substantial and may start before their mothers' pregnancy.

These findings highlight the importance of air quality during the preconception period in influencing children's health outcomes.

item.title: Managing the twin challenges of hypothyroidism and anaemia in India - MSN
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Air pollution amplifies dementia risk in cardiometabolic disease patients - healthy habits can help - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
Air pollution amplifies dementia risk in cardiometabolic disease patients - healthy habits can help

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Scientific Reports

The research highlights how lifestyle changes can help reduce the risks associated with dementia among patients with cardiometabolic diseases exacerbated by air pollution.

  • Patients with three cardiometabolic diseases have a higher risk of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and dementia.
  • Specific hazard ratios indicate significantly increased risks: 1.951 for MCI, 1.554 for all-cause dementia.
  • Ambient air pollution, particularly PM2.5 and NO2, worsens cognitive health outcomes.
  • Engaging in a healthy lifestyle can mitigate some risks associated with pollution exposure.
"The risk of developing mild cognitive impairment, all-cause dementia, Alzheimer's disease, and vascular dementia in patients with CMDs was 1.951, 1.554, 1.216, and 2.032 times higher than in those without CMDs, respectively."

The study underscores the importance of adopting healthier lifestyle practices to combat the escalating prevalence of dementia amid increasing pollution levels.

item.title: Groundbreaking Huntington Study Reveals Somatic DNA-Repeat Expansion - Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News
item.description:
Groundbreaking Huntington Study Reveals Somatic DNA-Repeat Expansion

Publication Date: N/A | Source: N/A

This study uncovers the mechanism by which the HTT gene mutation leads to Huntington’s disease, paving the way for potential therapies.

  • The mutation in the HTT gene causes Huntington’s disease.
  • It was found that the mutation initially seems harmless but later becomes toxic.
  • The research reveals how CAG repeat expansions over time contribute to cell death.
  • Using data from over 500,000 cells, researchers observed significant CAG repeat expansions in striatal projection neurons.
  • The findings have implications for potential therapies to delay symptom onset and disease progression.
“This is a really different way of thinking about how a mutation brings about a disease.” - Steve McCarroll, PhD

Overall, this study provides insights that could lead to new therapeutic strategies for Huntington’s as well as related disorders.

item.title: COVID-19 dramatically raises the risk of developing ME/CFS - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
COVID-19 Raises Risk of Developing ME/CFS

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: Journal of General Internal Medicine

The recent study examines the correlation between COVID-19 and the increased incidence of myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS), highlighting the urgent need for better diagnostics and care.

  • The study found a significant increase in the risk of developing ME/CFS after a SARS-CoV-2 infection.
  • 4.5% of participants with COVID-19 showed symptoms matching ME/CFS criteria at six months, compared to 0.6% in uninfected controls.
  • The prevalence of post-exertional malaise was reported by 24% of infected individuals.
  • 89% of diagnosed ME/CFS patients also had long COVID symptoms.
  • The study emphasized the importance of early recognition and comprehensive care strategies for post-COVID conditions.
"These findings emphasized the need for early recognition of ME/CFS symptoms following SARS-CoV-2 infections."

The growing body of evidence suggests that COVID-19 significantly increases the risk of ME/CFS, requiring urgent attention to public health responses and necessary healthcare interventions.

item.title: India: Wearable Tech Mimics Pain to Detect Stress - OpenGov Asia
item.description:
Wearable Tech Mimics Pain to Detect Stress

Publication Date: Unknown Source: OpenGov Asia

Scientists from JNCASR in Bengaluru have developed a wearable device that senses stress by mimicking the human body's response to pain, paving the way for efficient health monitoring systems.

  • The device uses a silver wire network embedded in stretchable material.
  • It detects strain and learns from it, mimicking pain responses seen in the human body.
  • This adaptive ability allows it to adjust its electrical response over time.
  • The technology could transform healthcare and robotics by providing real-time stress detection.
  • It's inspired by nociceptors, which detect pain and trigger protective responses.
  • Published in Materials Horizons by the Royal Society of Chemistry.
“This novel wearable device represents a significant step forward in the development of more intelligent, adaptable technology.”

This development signifies a major leap in creating technology that is more aligned with human physiological responses, enhancing the possibilities of healthcare and robotic applications.

item.title: Long overdue, short term regimen for TB set to be a game changer - The Hindu
item.description:
Short-term Regimen for MDR-TB: A Potential Game Changer

Published on: January 17, 2025 Source: The Hindu

Multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) poses significant health risks, particularly in India, where 27% of cases reported to the WHO in 2023 originated. New shorter treatment regimens, specifically the BPaL regimen, may revolutionize MDR-TB management.

  • MDR-TB has a high risk of death, with 30-40% mortality.
  • Current long treatments involve more drugs and are difficult to adhere to.
  • The BPaL regimen offers a promising alternative with fewer oral medications over a shorter duration.
  • Monitoring adherence and testing for drug susceptibility are crucial for effective treatment.
  • Health system preparedness and community education are essential for successful implementation.
“A shorter regimen is transformative but not the answer to all the issues that persist in TB.”

In conclusion, while the introduction of new regimens marks progress, comprehensive approaches addressing systemic issues in TB treatment and care are necessary for long-term success.

item.title: Review highlights current understanding of Nipah virus features - Medical Xpress
item.description:
Review Highlights Current Understanding of Nipah Virus Features

Publication Date: January 16, 2025 Source: Medical Xpress

Nipah virus (NiV), a zoonotic paramyxovirus, poses significant human health risks due to high fatality rates and potential for human-to-human transmission. A review titled "Nipah virus: epidemiology, pathogenesis, treatment, and prevention" discusses these features in the journal Frontiers of Medicine.

  • Nipah virus has recurrent outbreaks primarily in South and Southeast Asia, first identified in Malaysia in 1998.
  • The virus can infect a variety of hosts, with bats being the natural reservoir and pigs acting as intermediate hosts.
  • Human infections have occurred in multiple countries, including Malaysia, Singapore, and India.
  • NiV manifests with flu-like symptoms and severe neurological complications, with no specific antiviral treatment available.
  • Prevention measures include surveillance and changes in agricultural practices to reduce exposure.
  • Latest research discusses vaccine development, including virus-like and mRNA-based vaccines, although none are approved for human use yet.
The review underscores the need for a multidisciplinary approach to address the NiV threat, including the development of effective therapeutics and vaccines.

The findings highlight the importance of continued research and public health measures to mitigate the risks associated with Nipah virus.

item.title: Alcohol Consumption Linked to Seven Types of Cancer - University of Miami
item.description:
Alcohol Consumption Linked to Seven Types of Cancer

Publication Date: January 16, 2025 | Source: InventUM

The U.S. surgeon general has issued an advisory linking alcohol to seven types of cancer, emphasizing the need for warning labels on alcoholic beverages about this risk. Researchers at Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center stress the importance of this advisory in changing public behavior and oncology practices.

  • The surgeon general's report highlights that alcohol is the third-leading preventable cause of cancer.
  • Alcohol is linked to over 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 related deaths annually in the U.S.
  • The association between alcohol intake and increased cancer risk has been acknowledged for decades.
  • Experts are hopeful that labeling will lead to greater public awareness and behavior change regarding alcohol consumption.
“Alcohol consumption is certainly a worsening public health problem and we’re going to be in trouble if people continue drinking as they are.” - Dr. Patricia Jones

This advisory signals a significant opportunity to address alcohol consumption as a modifiable risk factor for cancer.

item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Indian scientists develop wearable devices to detect stress - Greater Kashmir
item.description:
Indian Scientists Develop Wearable Devices to Detect Stress

Publication Date: January 16, Source: New Delhi

The Jawaharlal Nehru Centre for Advanced Scientific Research in Bengaluru has created a novel wearable device capable of detecting stress.

  • The device uses a silver wire network on stretchable material to sense strain.
  • It mimics pain perception and adapts its electrical response to stretching.
  • The technology could enhance health monitoring systems that respond to stress in real-time.
“These pain-like responses in the device pave the way for future smart wearable systems that can help doctors detect stress,” researchers stated.

The innovative approach could help mitigate the health threats posed by stress, such as high blood pressure and heart disease.

item.title: Surprise finding sheds light on what causes Huntington's disease, a devastating fatal brain disorder - Hindustan Times
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Drinking Green Tea Daily Can Help In Keeping Your Brain Healthy, Reveals Study - News18
item.description:
Drinking Green Tea Daily Can Help In Keeping Your Brain Healthy, Reveals Study

Date: January 16, 2025, Source: News18

Recent research published in npj Science of Food suggests that daily consumption of green tea can contribute to better brain health, reducing the risk of cognitive decline and providing protective benefits as people age.

  • Green tea improves cognitive function and may help prevent age-related mental decline.
  • Participants consuming 600 ml of green tea daily showed 3% less brain damage compared to those drinking 200 ml or less.
  • Green tea is rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds, particularly epigallocatechin gallate.
  • In comparison, coffee did not show significant benefits for brain health, emphasizing the advantages of green tea.
"Drinking about three cups of green tea a day could be beneficial for brain health."

This study highlights the potential health benefits of green tea, suggesting it is a preferable beverage for those concerned about cognitive health.

item.title: Tanzania says no sign of Marburg outbreak in the country - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Tanzania Reports No Signs of Marburg Outbreak

Published on: Jan 17, 2025

Source: Hindustan Times

The government of Tanzania has confirmed that no individuals in the country have tested positive for the Marburg virus, despite reports from the World Health Organization of suspected cases.

  • The WHO reported at least eight deaths believed to be from the Marburg virus in northwest Tanzania.
  • Tanzania's health minister stated that all lab results for suspected cases returned negative.
  • Victims displayed typical symptoms associated with Marburg virus, including headache, high fever, and vomiting blood.
  • The Marburg virus has a fatality rate as high as 88% and is related to the Ebola virus.
  • In response to the suspected cases, Tanzania deployed experts to investigate and collect specimens for testing.
  • Tanzania experienced its first Marburg outbreak in 2023, with nine cases and six deaths reported.
  • The government has enhanced disease surveillance measures following these reports.
“As of 15th January 2025, laboratory results for all suspected individuals were negative for Marburg virus.” - Jenista Mhagama, Health Minister

The Tanzanian government emphasizes its preparedness and response to viral outbreaks, particularly after criticism during the COVID-19 pandemic for data transparency and preventive measures.

item.title: NIMH awards $1.5 million grant for long COVID neurological research - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
NIMH awards $1.5 million grant for long COVID neurological research

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Not specified

The National Institute of Mental Health has awarded a significant grant of $1.5 million to Jianyang Du, PhD, for research on neurological disorders caused by long COVID-19.

  • The project will explore the cellular mechanisms of long COVID.
  • Dr. Du's team has developed a mouse model to study the infection effects.
  • The research aims to unveil how the virus impacts brain function.

“I would like to express my gratitude to Dr. Qian Ge, my postdoctoral fellow, for her significant contributions to the grant application... the progress of this work would not have been possible without his generous assistance.”
— Dr. Jianyang Du, PhD

This research may lead to new treatments that alleviate the suffering associated with long COVID and address health disparities.

item.title: Sierra Leone Reports First Mpox Cases as Democratic Republic of Congo Accelerates Vaccine Drive - Health Policy Watch
item.description:
Sierra Leone Reports First Mpox Cases As Democratic Republic Of Congo Accelerates Vaccine Drive

Date: January 10, 2024 | Source: Health Policy Watch

A new mpox outbreak in Sierra Leone and a rising case toll across Africa are fueling urgent calls for stronger containment efforts, even as the Democratic Republic of Congo speeds up its mpox vaccine drive.

  • Sierra Leone has reported its first mpox cases, with two confirmed infections having no known travel history.
  • Health authorities are monitoring 25 contacts linked to the confirmed cases.
  • Africa has seen 77,888 mpox cases over the past year, with 1,321 deaths reported in 2024.
  • Dr. Jean Kaseya described the outbreak as a major public health emergency.
  • China recently reported its first case of Clade 1b mpox, connected to a traveler from Africa.
  • Rwanda’s successful Marburg virus response is highlighted as a model for epidemic control.
“We are seeing a sharp increase in cases compared to 2023, and this remains a significant threat to public health in Africa.” — Dr. Jean Kaseya

The emergence of mpox cases in Sierra Leone, along with rising infections across Africa, poses critical challenges that require immediate global collaboration and local containment efforts.

item.title: Cancer deaths decline in US, but rates among women and young adults are rising: Report - The Times of India
item.description:
Cancer deaths decline in US, but rates among women and young adults are rising: Report

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Health News

Cancer death rates in the US have decreased overall; however, there is a concerning uptick in rates among women and young adults. This report highlights the contrasting trends that merit attention for future healthcare strategies.

  • Cancer mortality rates overall have seen a decline.
  • Women and young adults are experiencing rising cancer incidence and mortality rates.
  • Public health responses and targeted interventions are urgently needed to address these changes.
"Despite overall progress in combatting cancer, the rising rates among vulnerable populations indicate a need for renewed focus and research." - Health Expert

The divergent trends in cancer mortality reveal an ongoing public health challenge, calling for enhanced awareness and proactive measures to prevent and treat cancer in affected demographics.

item.title: TiLoop Mesh implant offers hope & healing to breast cancer patient - The Times of India
item.description:
TiLoop Mesh Implant Offers Hope and Healing to Breast Cancer Patient

Publication Date: N/A, Source: N/A

The TiLoop mesh implant presents a promising advancement in the treatment and recovery of breast cancer patients, potentially improving their quality of life.

  • Introduction of the TiLoop mesh implant as a new treatment option.
  • Positive patient outcomes and enhanced recovery experiences reported.
  • Focus on the innovation in breast cancer surgery and support.
"This implant has changed my life and given me hope for the future." – Patient testimonial

This innovative approach could redefine recovery strategies for breast cancer, highlighting the importance of research in improving patient outcomes.

item.title: Fiber-rich food has anti-cancer properties, says study - The Times of India
item.description:
Fiber-rich food has anti-cancer properties, says study

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Not specified

This article examines the findings of a recent study that highlights the potential anti-cancer properties of fiber-rich foods. It suggests that incorporating these foods into the diet might help reduce cancer risk.

  • The study found a strong correlation between high fiber intake and lower cancer rates.
  • Fiber-rich foods include fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes.
  • Participants who consumed more fiber had a significantly lower risk of developing various types of cancer.
  • The researchers emphasized the importance of dietary choices in cancer prevention.
"Increasing your fiber intake can be a simple yet effective way to improve your overall health and potentially reduce cancer risk," said the lead researcher.

The findings of this study underscore the significance of dietary fiber in our health and open up discussions on nutrition as a key factor in cancer prevention.

item.title: Dance programme brings joy to seniors with Parkinson’s - The Times of India
item.description:
Dance Programme Brings Joy to Seniors with Parkinson’s

Publication Date: Not specified
Source: Not specified

This article discusses a dance program aimed at enhancing the quality of life for seniors suffering from Parkinson’s disease through the joy of movement and social interaction.

  • The programme incorporates various dance styles tailored to seniors.
  • Participants report increased mobility and reduced symptoms of Parkinson’s.
  • Social interaction during the sessions helps build community and reduce isolation.
  • Healthcare professionals endorse the benefits of dance therapy for Parkinson’s patients.
“I never thought I could move like this again. It’s not just about dancing; it’s about feeling alive,” a participant remarked.

The program highlights the therapeutic power of dance in improving both physical and emotional health for seniors.
